Subject: Re: [neat] New HybrID Paper (combining indirect and direct encodings)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=3xTgd6XOGIeaCceoEnBvpXFsTFcw1h7qbfzamP0NUzT5A-RwICn4

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=utf-8

Hello Colin,

Thank you for the nice email. We are very glad you liked the =
paper. 

The idea you propose is interesting! A similar idea based off of w=
hat you propose, in the MAP-Elites spirit, could be to have bins for the be=
st indirect-encoding only performer, as well as bins for pure direct encodi=
ngs, as well as combinations (perhaps to different degrees=E2=80=A6as in di=
fferent weighted combinations of the two, or direct encodings with smaller =
norms, etc.), and then=E2=80=94importantly=E2=80=94offspring can end up in =
any bin they are the best of. That could encourage pure indirect encodings =
to evolve, but the algorithm would always be checking whether those work in=
 combination with direct encodings too. 

Inspired by some of Nick Cheney=
=E2=80=99s nice recent work, you could also protect new combinations for a =
while to give them some time to fine tune before seeing if they end up bein=
g the elite in the bin (e.g. an age-layered stratification within a bin, wh=
ich itself comes from Greg Hornby=E2=80=99s ALPS idea). 

Lots of fun ideas=
, all variants off of your nice idea.

Unfortunately we do not have the ban=
dwidth to investigate these ideas for the foreseeable future, but if you (o=
r anyone else does), please let us know if they pan out. 

Thanks for shari=
ng your reaction to our paper. 

Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Loy and Edith Ha=
rris Assistant Professor in Computer Science
Director, Evolving Artificial =
Intelligence Lab <http://evolvingai.org/>
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@u=
wyo.edu <mailto:jeffclune@...>
jeffclune.com <http://jeffclune.com/>
>=
 On Mar 26, 2017, at 9:11 AM, Colin Green colin.green1@... [neat] <ne=
at@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
> 
> 
> Thanks to Lucas and Jeff. It's a useful =
piece of research and a very thorough paper! 
> 
> There's a mention toward=
s the end of the possibility of co-evolving indirect and direct encodings -=
 I was having the same thought while reading, as that would essentially be =
a ensemble (a mini ensemble of two). Technically we could do this with any =
encoding, e.g. maybe evolving *pairs* of NEAT genomes would be superior to =
single genomes (technically a single 'compound' genome). But of course with=
 the two very different encodings there's the possibility that we might tap=
 into the strengths of both such.
> 
> The poor performance of offset NEAT =
does seem to suggest that learning direct encodings early can basically pre=
vent the indirect encoding from finding the regularities that are there, i.=
e. the direct encoding immediately starts to obfuscate them (make the fitne=
ss landscape more complex to search), so it makes sense from that point of =
view that the approach has problems, and thus we can probably expect co-evo=
lved genomes to exhibit the same problem.
> 
> Perhaps though the indirect =
encodings could be scored separately, so two scores - one based on the indi=
rect encoding genome only, and another for the compound genome score. We th=
en arrange genomes in a 2D cartesian grid with one fitness along the X-axis=
, and compound fitness on the Y-Axis. We can then define a 'final' fitness =
score as the distance from the origin i.e. distance =3D sqrt(x^2 + y^2).
> =

> This has the effect of selecting some genomes that have good indirect en=
codings when operating independently, but not when their direct encoding is=
 applied. This allows the indirect encoding to evolve independently of the =
direct encoding, but at some point if the combination works well then that =
starts to get selected for, but it still competes for selection with the in=
direct only encodings, such that 'branching off' into evolving the combined=
 pairs is no longer a distinct event, it's just part of the search space be=
ing explored.
> 
> Further, a weighting or scaling might be applied to the =
X-axis or the Y-axis scores to assign some degree of precedence of preferen=
ce to the indirect-only encoding fitness.
> 
> Make sense?  
> 
> Thanks ag=
ain.
> 
> Colin
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_AF9E5F0B-5DC0-41E1-AFCA-92D422C83B7E

Content-Type: text/html;
	charset=utf-8

lass=3D"">On Mar 26, 2017, at 9:11 AM, Colin Green <a href=3D"mailto:colin.=

ote:</div><br class=3D"Apple-interchange-newline"><div class=3D""><div id=
=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"font-size: 13px; font-family: Arial, helvetica, cl=
ean, sans-serif; font-style: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight=
: normal; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: auto; text-align: start; text-in=
dent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: auto; word-sp=
acing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; background-color: rgb(255, 255,=

eight: 1.22em; z-index: 1;" class=3D""><div id=3D"ygrp-text" style=3D"line-=

: 1.22em; margin: 0px 0px 1em;" class=3D""><br class=3D"webkit-block-placeh=
older"></div><div dir=3D"ltr" style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D"">Tha=
nks to Lucas and Jeff. It's a useful piece of research and a very thorough =
paper! <div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""><br style=3D"lin=
e-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""></div><div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" cla=
ss=3D"">There's a mention towards the end of the possibility of co-evolving=
 indirect and direct encodings - I was having the same thought while readin=
g, as that would essentially be a ensemble (a mini ensemble of two). Techni=
cally we could do this with any encoding, e.g. maybe evolving *pairs* of NE=
AT genomes would be superior to single genomes (technically a single 'compo=
und' genome). But of course with the two very different encodings there's t=
he possibility that we might tap into the strengths of both such.</div><div=
 style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em=
;" class=3D""></div><div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D"">The poor=
 performance of offset NEAT does seem to suggest that learning direct encod=
ings early can basically prevent the indirect encoding from finding the reg=
ularities that are there, i.e. the direct encoding immediately starts to ob=
fuscate them (make the fitness landscape more complex to search), so it mak=
es sense from that point of view that the approach has problems, and thus w=
e can probably expect co-evolved genomes to exhibit the same problem.</div>=
<div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""><br style=3D"line-height: 1.=
22em;" class=3D""></div><div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D"">Perh=
aps though the indirect encodings could be scored separately, so two scores=
 - one based on the indirect encoding genome only, and another for the comp=
ound genome score. We then arrange genomes in a 2D cartesian grid with one =
fitness along the X-axis, and compound fitness on the Y-Axis. We can then d=
efine a 'final' fitness score as the distance from the origin i.e. distance=
 =3D sqrt(x^2 + y^2).</div><div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""><=
br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""></div><div style=3D"line-heigh=
t: 1.22em;" class=3D"">This has the effect of selecting some genomes that h=
ave good indirect encodings when operating independently, but not when thei=
r direct encoding is applied. This allows the indirect encoding to evolve i=
ndependently of the direct encoding, but at some point if the combination w=
orks well then that starts to get selected for, but it still competes for s=
election with the indirect only encodings, such that 'branching off' into e=
volving the combined pairs is no longer a distinct event, it's just part of=
 the search space being explored.</div><div style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" =
class=3D""><br style=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D""></div><div style=
=3D"line-height: 1.22em;" class=3D"">Further, a weighting or scaling might =
